questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, is brought to the emergency department at 39 weeks' gestation in active labor. Her first child was delivered at 40 weeks' gestation by elective cesarean section due to a limited range of motion in her hip. The patient has sickle cell disease. She has had multiple episodes of acute chest syndrome and has required several transfusions in the past. An uncomplicated repeat cesarean section is performed, and a 2.7-kg (6-lb) infant is delivered with approx. 550 mL blood loss. Perioperatively, she received one dose of intravenous cefazolin. Following the surgery, the patient continues to bleed, and she receives a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells. One hour later, the patient begins to have flank pain and appears to be in acute distress. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 99/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Foley catheter shows dark brown urine. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Serum antibodies against Class I HLA antigens
Low levels of serum IgA immunoglobulins
Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest x-ray

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum antibodies directed against donor HLA antigens have been associated with febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTRs), as the antibodies may bind to HLA antigens on residual donor leukocytes in blood products and possibly stimulate the release of inflammatory cytokines, which could cause fever and tachypnea. However, FNHTR does not result in hypotension. More importantly, the presence of hemoglobinuria and flank pain indicate that the patient has intravascular hemolysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Low levels of serum IgA immunoglobulins would be consistent with selective IgA deficiency. Patients with selective IgA deficiency have antibodies against IgA, which then mediate an allergic response and anaphylaxis during transfusion of blood products that incidentally contain donor IgA. While this patient's acute distress, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension might be consistent with an anaphylactic response, the absence of corresponding angioedema, pulmonary (dyspnea, wheezing) and skin findings (urticaria, pruritus, flush) are not consistent with this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Positive blood cultures in the postpartum period might suggest a diagnosis of puerperal sepsis, which can manifest with fever, hypotension, tachypnea, and tachycardia. While this patient currently has a number of findings that might raise concerns of sepsis, there is no evidence of a surgical site infection (e.g., purulent discharge from the wound), endometritis/parametritis (e.g., foul-smelling lochia, subinvolution of the uterus, cervical motion tenderness), or peritonitis (e.g., abdominal guarding, rigidity) to suggest a focus for puerperal sepsis in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

A positive direct Coombs test indicates that RBCs in the patient's blood have bound antibodies. This laboratory result would be consistent with a diagnosis of AHTR, in which donor RBC lysis is mediated by preformed antibodies in the patient's serum. AHTRs are most commonly due to ABO incompatibility, and less commonly due to a mismatch and incompatibility of minor RBC antigens (e.g., anti-Jka, anti-Rh, etc.). Patients with a history of previous transfusions, especially those with sickle cell disease, are more likely to be subject to alloimmunization against foreign blood product antigens and subsequently have transfusion-related complications, including but not limited to AHTRs.

See “Overview of immunological transfusion reactions” table.
Image Description:

A test used to detect hemolytic antibodies bound to RBCs (direct Coombs test) or freely circulating in the serum (indirect Coombs test).

1. The direct Coombs test is used to detect hemolytic antibodies or complement bound to the surface of a patient's erythrocytes. It is used to differentiate between autoimmune and nonimmune hemolytic anemias and to diagnose hemolytic diseases of the fetus and newborn.

2. The indirect Coombs test is used to detect hemolytic anti-RBC IgG antibodies (against foreign RBC antigens) present in a patient's serum. It is used to screen for maternal anti-D IgG antibodies (detection of hemolytic disease of the newborn) and to crossmatch blood before transfusions.

E) INCORRECT:

Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates that develop within 6 hours of transfusion of a blood product may indicate either transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) or transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Both TRALI and TACO can manifest with acute distress, tachypnea, and tachycardia, and patients with TRALI may also develop fever and hypotension. However, patients with TRALI or TACO would present with hypoxemia as a result of respiratory insufficiency and bilateral crackles due to pulmonary edema. Moreover, patients with TACO are usually afebrile and hypertensive rather than hypotensive, given their state of circulatory overload. Together with the normal SpO2, the absence of these findings makes these diagnoses unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient developed a fever, hypotension, tachypnea, tachycardia, flank pain, and hemoglobinuria within 1–2 hours of receiving a blood transfusion, which is consistent with an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with severe menorrhagia for 3 days. She also reports dizziness. She has hypertension, for which she takes lisinopril. She appears pale. Her temperature is 37.5˚C (99.5˚F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Pelvic examination shows a vaginal vault with dark maroon blood and clots but no active source of bleeding. Her hemoglobin concentration is 5.9 g/dL. Crystalloid fluids are administered and she is transfused with 4 units of crossmatched packed red blood cells. Two hours later, she has shortness of breath and dull chest pressure. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 170/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. Diffuse crackles are heard over the lower lung fields on auscultation. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral hazy opacities. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening type 1 hypersensitivity reaction that can occur during blood product transfusion and manifests with bronchospasm, urticaria, and hypotension (shock). This patient presents with crackles, not wheezes, and lacks other features of anaphylaxis. Additionally, the delayed time course in this patient's presentation makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a rare but dangerous complication of transfusion of blood products that usually occurs within the first 6 hours after transfusion and can manifest with acute dyspnea and diffuse bilateral opacities on chest x-ray. However, hypotension and fever would also be expected, whereas this patient is hypertensive and afebrile.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism (PE) can manifest with tachycardia, dyspnea, and hypoxia, as seen in this patient. However, a chest x-ray is usually normal in PE or shows nonspecific findings. In addition, PEs are usually associated with hypotension (rather than hypertension) and the chest pain in PE is classically pleuritic, rather than a dull chest pressure. PE would also not explain this patient's S3 gallop.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction manifests with fever, chills, nausea, hypotension, and flank pain and typically occurs during transfusion of incompatible blood products. Although symptoms can include shortness of breath, it is not associated with pulmonary edema or an S3 gallop, and the time course of this patient's presentation is not consistent with this diagnosis. Furthermore, hemolytic transfusion reaction is unlikely to occur with blood products that have been crossmatched correctly.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypertensive emergency is defined as severe hypertension (> 180/120 mm Hg) with end-organ damage, such as decompensated heart failure, encephalopathy, acute kidney injury, etc. While this patient has a history of hypertension and has symptoms of heart failure (pulmonary edema, S3), she was initially hypotensive on presentation and her blood pressure of 170/90 mm Hg is not consistent with this diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) refers to volume overload that has developed secondary to the transfusion of blood products. It generally occurs within 12 hours of transfusion and is characterized by hypertension, wide pulse pressure, and evidence of volume overload (pulmonary edema, S3 gallop, jugular venous distention). Risk increases with the number of units transfused and can be minimized by increasing time intervals between transfusions and limiting the rate of intravenous administration. Treatment usually involves the use of supplemental oxygen and mobilization of fluid with diuresis.

See “Differentiating between transfusion-related acute lung injury and transfusion-associated circulatory overload” table.
questions.hint: This patient's hypoxia, bibasilar crackles, and hazy opacities on chest x-ray suggest pulmonary edema.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with sickle cell disease and at 39-weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department in active labor. She has had multiple episodes of acute chest syndrome and has required several transfusions in the past. She has a prolonged vaginal delivery complicated by postpartum bleeding, and she receives a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells. One hour later, the patient experiences acute flank pain. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 95/55 mm Hg. Foley catheter shows dark brown urine. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest x-ray
Serum antibodies against class I HLA antigens
Low levels of serum IgA immunoglobulins

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates that develop within 6 hours of transfusion of a blood product may indicate either transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) or transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Both TRALI and TACO could present with acute distress, tachypnea, and tachycardia, as seen in this patient, and patients with TRALI may also develop fever and hypotension. However, patients with TRALI or TACO would present with hypoxemia as a result of respiratory insufficiency and bilateral crackles due to pulmonary edema. Moreover, patients with TACO are usually afebrile and hypertensive rather than hypotensive, given their state of circulatory overload. Together with the normal SpO2, the absence of these findings makes these diagnoses unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum antibodies directed against donor HLA antigens have been associated with febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTRs), as the antibodies may bind to HLA antigens on residual donor leukocytes in blood products and possibly stimulate the release of inflammatory cytokines. This reaction could cause this patient's fever and tachypnea, but FNHTR does not result in hypotension. More importantly, the presence of hemoglobinuria and flank pain indicate that the patient instead has intravascular hemolysis.

C) CORRECT:

A positive direct Coombs test indicates that RBCs in the patient's blood have bound antibodies. This laboratory result would be consistent with a diagnosis of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR), in which donor RBC lysis is mediated by preformed antibodies in the patient's serum. AHTRs are most commonly due to ABO incompatibility, and less commonly due to a mismatch and incompatibility of minor RBC antigens (e.g., anti-Jka, anti-Rh). Patients with a history of previous transfusions, especially those with SCD, are more likely to be subject to alloimmunization against foreign blood product antigens and subsequently have transfusion-related complications, including but not limited to AHTRs.

See “Overview of immunological transfusion reactions” table.
Image Description:

TRALI: Transfusion-related acute lung injury; Ag: antigen

D) INCORRECT:

Positive blood cultures in the postpartum period might suggest a diagnosis of puerperal sepsis, which can present with fever, hypotension, tachypnea, and tachycardia. While this patient currently has a number of findings that might raise concerns of sepsis, there is no evidence of a surgical site infection (e.g., purulent discharge from the wound), endometritis/parametritis (e.g., foul-smelling lochia, subinvolution of the uterus, cervical motion tenderness), or peritonitis (e.g., abdominal guarding, rigidity) to suggest a focus for puerperal sepsis in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Low levels of serum IgA immunoglobulins would be consistent with selective IgA deficiency. Patients with selective IgA deficiency have antibodies against IgA, which then mediate an allergic response and anaphylaxis during transfusion of blood products that incidentally contain donor IgA. While this patient's acute distress, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension might be consistent with an anaphylactic response, the absence of corresponding angioedema, pulmonary (dyspnea, wheezing) and skin findings (urticaria, pruritus, flush) are not consistent with this diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient developed fever, hypotension, tachypnea, tachycardia, flank pain, and likely hemoglobinuria (dark brown urine) within 1–2 hours of receiving a blood transfusion, which is consistent with an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR). AHTR is a type II hypersensitivity reaction, in which preformed antibodies cause activation of the complement system (C5-C9), which results in intravascular hemolysis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman who underwent urgent coronary artery bypass grafting develops sudden-onset of difficulty breathing shortly after postoperative transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells because of moderate blood loss. She has alcohol use disorder, and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years. Her temperature is 38.3ºC (100.8ºF), respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 88/57 mmHg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 72%. Physical examination shows profuse sweating and cyanosis. There is no jugular venous distension and no peripheral edema. A chest x-ray shows bilateral alveolar and interstitial infiltrates and a normal cardiac silhouette. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's transfusion reaction?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long storage of blood products can lead to the leakage and accumulation of cytokines. These cytokines can induce febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions, which manifest in the recipient with fever and chills. However, this patient's hypotension, pulmonary distress, and infiltrates on chest x-ray are not consistent with this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

ABO incompatibility is the most common cause of acute hemolytic transfusion reactions (AHTR), which can manifest with fever, hypotension, and dyspnea, as seen here. AHTR typically occurs during or within one hour of the transfusion. However, typical symptoms include flank pain, signs of hemolysis (e.g., jaundice), gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea), allergic symptoms (e.g., pruritis, urticaria) and complications such as renal failure, none of which are seen in this patient. Additionally, diffuse infiltrations on chest x-ray are not typically seen in AHTR.

C) INCORRECT:

A delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction upon re-exposure to antigens (i.e., anamnestic antibody response) can occur during a transfusion in patients who were previously sensitized to specific RBC antigens (e.g., Rhesus factor) during transfusion or pregnancy. This leads to a rapid increase in antibodies that bind to donor RBCs and causes extravascular hemolysis. However, this reaction would occur days or weeks after transfusion and would manifest with signs of hemolysis (e.g., jaundice) rather than respiratory distress and lung infiltrates.

D) CORRECT:

Activation of primed neutrophils within the recipient's pulmonary capillaries is thought to be the pathomechanism of transfusion-related acute lung injury. Activation occurs after exposure to soluble factors (anti-leukocyte antibodies or lipids) in the donor blood. The result is diffuse damage of pulmonary endothelial cells, which leads to leakage of interstitial fluid into the alveoli, causing an ARDS-like reaction with respiratory distress, fever, hypoxemia, and diffuse infiltrates on chest x-ray, as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

TRALI: Transfusion-related acute lung injury; Ag: antigen

E) INCORRECT:

Type I hypersensitivity reactions are typically caused by anti-IgA IgG in recipients with IgA deficiency. Preformed antibodies bind to IgA on the surface of donor RBCs and trigger mast cell degranulation, causing symptoms such as hypotension and respiratory distress, as seen here. However, other features of anaphylaxis, such as urticaria and pruritus, would be expected as well. Furthermore, anaphylaxis is not associated with diffuse infiltrations on chest x-ray.
questions.hint: This patient developed respiratory distress, fever, hypotension, and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema within 6 hours of receiving a blood transfusion, which is consistent with a transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI).

questions.text:
Two hours after undergoing a platelet transfusion, a 55-year-old man develops fever, chills, and headache. He was admitted to the hospital 4 hours ago for an uncontrolled nosebleed and was treated with anterior nasal packing and an oxymetazoline spray. The platelet count at the time of admission was 33,000/mm3. Medical history is remarkable for multiple myeloma complicated by bone marrow failure. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 143/96 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor, scattered petechiae on his upper and lower extremities, and gauze packing in the nasal cavity. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11 g/dL


Leukocyte count
4300/mm3



Platelet count
57,000/mm3



Serum



Total bilirubin
0.4 mg/dL


Lactate dehydrogenase
90 U/L


A direct antiglobulin test (Coombs test) is negative. Blood cultures grow no organisms. Which of the following measures would most likely have prevented this patient's transfusion-related complication?

choices.text: Using platelet concentrate only from male donors and screening for antineutrophil antibodies
Leukoreduction of the platelet concentrate before storage
System-based training of health care personnel for proper patient identification

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Premedication with antihistamines is used in patients with a history of moderate to severe allergic transfusion reactions to reduce the incidence and severity of subsequent reactions. Allergic reactions are common in patients receiving platelet transfusions and usually develop within 4 hours of transfusion. However, the absence of wheezing, hypotension, and shortness of breath makes a severe allergic transfusion reaction unlikely. Premedication with antihistamines is not indicated for FNHTR.

B) INCORRECT:

Using platelet concentrate only from male donors and screening for antineutrophil antibodies decreases the risk of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), which most commonly occurs after platelet transfusion and manifests with fever within 6 hours of transfusion. TRALI cases are more commonly associated with female and multiparous donors than male donors. However, TRALI is associated with dyspnea, hypotonia, hypotension, and findings of pulmonary edema (e.g., crackles on auscultation), none of which are seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Slowing the rate of transfusion helps to prevent transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), which typically occurs during or within 12 hours of transfusion. However, TACO is associated with findings of hypervolemia (e.g., dyspnea, S3 gallop, jugular venous distention, hypertension) and pulmonary edema (e.g., crackles on auscultation).

D) CORRECT:

Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTRs) result from the leakage of preformed cytokines produced by donor leukocytes and accumulated during the storage of blood products; lysis of donor leukocytes by preformed recipient antibodies has also been implicated. Prestorage leukoreduction, e.g., by ultrafiltration, decreases the number of donor leukocytes available within blood products and, therefore, helps to prevent FNHTRs. FNHTRs are a diagnosis of exclusion; the first step in the management of suspected FNHTR is the cessation of transfusion to rule out more serious transfusion reactions (e.g., acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, transfusion-associated sepsis, transfusion-related acute lung injury). An antipyretic such as acetaminophen can be given to treat the fever and, if the patient remains stable without new symptoms, the transfusion can be recommenced at a slow rate.

E) INCORRECT:

System-based training of health care personnel for proper patient identification can reduce the incidence of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) due to ABO mismatch (a never event), which manifests with fever and chills within the first 24 hours after transfusion. However, patients also typically present with flank pain, features of hemolysis (e.g., elevated LDH, indirect hyperbilirubinemia), and a positive direct antiglobulin test, none of which are seen here. Unlike RBC concentrates, platelet concentrates are usually transfused without crossmatching because ABO antigens are poorly expressed on platelets; therefore, proper patient identification would not help to prevent platelet-associated transfusion reactions.
questions.hint: The combination of fever, chills, and headache occurring 1–6 hours posttransfusion in a hemodynamically stable patient with no evidence of hemolysis (i.e., normal LDH and total bilirubin), a negative direct antiglobulin test, and negative blood culture is consistent with febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR).

questions.text: A 24-year-old man develops respiratory distress in the postoperative ward 2 hours after surgical repair of an open midshaft fracture of the right femur. He was brought to the emergency department 4 hours ago after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. On arrival, he was oriented to person, place, and time. During the procedure, he received 6 units of packed red blood cells, 1 unit of platelets, and 4 units of fresh frozen plasma. On admission to the postoperative ward, his vitals were within normal limits. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Now, his temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 78%. Bibasilar crackles are heard on auscultation. Chest x-ray shows diffuse, bilateral infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's deterioration?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a transfusion reaction caused by the activation of the recipient's granulocytes by soluble factors (e.g., antibodies) in the donor's blood. Activated granulocytes release proinflammatory mediators that increase the vascular permeability, resulting in plasma transudation into the pulmonary interstitium and consequent noncardiogenic pulmonary edema. TRALI typically occurs during or within 6 hours of transfusion. Patients usually present with hypoxemic respiratory insufficiency, features of pulmonary edema (e.g., crackles, bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray), and signs of hypovolemia (hypotension, tachycardia). Signs of hypovolemia distinguish TRALI from transfusion-associated circulatory overload, which, in contrast to TRALI, characteristically manifests with findings of volume overload (e.g., elevated blood pressure, S3 gallop, jugular venous distension). Immediate cessation of any ongoing transfusion followed by supportive treatment with respiratory and circulatory support is recommended.
Image Description:

TRALI: Transfusion-related acute lung injury; Ag: antigen

B) INCORRECT:

Postoperative bronchospasm is a common complication following general anesthesia and typically manifests with sudden-onset respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and tachycardia. However, lung auscultation typically shows wheezing, which is not seen here. Moreover, bibasilar crackles and diffuse, bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray are not characteristic of bronchospasm.

C) INCORRECT:

Sepsis can manifest with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, tachycardia, and fever. Although this patient fulfills the diagnostic criteria for systemic inflammatory response syndrome (i.e., heart rate > 90/min and respiratory rate > 20/min), a diagnosis of sepsis requires a suspected or confirmed underlying infection. This patient had no signs of infection on admission, and wound infections and/or hospital-acquired pneumonia typically do not develop within 4 hours.

D) INCORRECT:

Fat embolism can manifest with hypoxemic respiratory distress, signs of hypovolemia, and diffuse, bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray (as a result of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema). However, neurological symptoms (e.g., altered mental status) would also be expected, and the symptoms of fat embolism typically develop 12–72 hours after the inciting event.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient after physical trauma

Parenchymal opacities (green overlay) are seen in both lungs, predominantly in the lower zones. No pleural effusions are visible (indicated by red overlay). The cardiac silhouette is not enlarged. A right central line is present (yellow outline). The radiopaque line on a nasogastric tube (blue overlay) can be traced into the mid-thorax, beyond which it is not well seen.

Nonspecific homogeneous or heterogeneous opacities may become visible on chest radiographs in various locations about 24–48 hours after an insult that results in pulmonary fat embolism. A normal cardiac silhouette size and absence of Kerley lines, pleural effusions, and pulmonary venous hypertension can help exclude a diagnosis of cardiogenic edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Volume overload can manifest with respiratory distress and pulmonary edema after surgery that involves aggressive hemodynamic support. However, signs of hypervolemia (e.g., hypertension, S3 gallop, jugular venous distension) rather than hypovolemia are expected in a patient with volume overload.
questions.hint: This patient presents with hypoxemic respiratory insufficiency, features of pulmonary edema (e.g., crackles, bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray), and signs of hypovolemia (hypotension, tachycardia) following major surgery that required aggressive hemodynamic support, including blood products.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman suddenly develops difficulty breathing, chills, and general pruritus 20 minutes after starting a red blood cell transfusion. She also reports pain in her back and at the IV site. She has chronic lymphocytic leukemia that is currently treated with chlorambucil and rituximab. She has received weekly red blood cell transfusions for chemotherapy-induced anemia over the past 6 months. She also has hypertension that is well-controlled with lisinopril. She appears to be in acute distress. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), respirations are 25/min, pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 95/65 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm, flushed skin. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination is normal. The transfusion is stopped immediately and the patient receives 100% oxygen via nasal cannula and IV saline. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Evaluate complete blood count and hemolytic indices

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measurement of anti-IgA antibodies, as well as IgA levels, can be performed in patients with anaphylactic transfusion reactions, which are more common in patients with selective IgA deficiency. Although anaphylactic transfusion reaction also manifests with respiratory distress, hypotension, and tachycardia, back pain and pain at the IV site are not characteristic of anaphylaxis and instead suggest AHTR. Moreover, in a patient with respiratory distress due to anaphylaxis, wheezing on lung auscultation is expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Complete blood count and hemolytic indices are important additional tests for evaluating patients with suspected AHTR. However, a different step is required first to confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

A chest x-ray can be used in the evaluation of patients with suspected pulmonary transfusion complications, such as transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) and transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Both of these complications can manifest with fever and respiratory distress that develop acutely either during or within hours of transfusion. However, a normal pulmonary examination makes pulmonary complications less likely. Moreover, general pruritus, back pain, and pain at the IV site are not features of these conditions.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with suspected AHTR, transfusion should be discontinued immediately and supportive measures such as supplemental oxygen (in patients with signs of respiratory distress) and fluid resuscitation (to prevent hypotension and reduce the risk of free hemoglobin-induced kidney injury) should be administered. The most common cause of AHTR is ABO incompatibility with transfused blood products due to errors in patient or sample identification and/or labeling. Therefore, the transfusion service should be contacted to undertake a clerical check on both the transfused blood product and the patient information. The patient should then have blood drawn to repeat patient and donor ABO typing and crossmatching and to undergo direct Coombs testing. Additional laboratory studies that should be obtained to support the diagnosis include a complete blood count, hemolytic indices, coagulation studies, and a basic metabolic panel.

E) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures should be obtained in patients with suspected transfusion-associated sepsis, which can manifest with fever, chills, respiratory distress, tachycardia, and hypotension. However, a hyperacute onset of symptoms (20 minutes in this case) is not typical for bacterial sepsis. Moreover, transfusion-associated sepsis is rare. This patient most likely has an AHTR, in which blood cultures are not needed. If transfusion-associated sepsis is suspected, blood cultures should be obtained from both the patient and the remaining blood product.
questions.hint: This patient's acute respiratory distress, fever, chills, hypotension, general pruritus, and back pain as well as pain at the IV site during a red blood cell transfusion are suggestive of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR).

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman hospitalized with acute myeloid leukemia suddenly develops acute respiratory distress and hypoxemia. She is intubated, and mechanical ventilation is initiated.
Prior to this episode, she was receiving induction therapy with cytarabine and daunorubicin — and had completed a course of cefepime yesterday for neutropenic fever. Overall, her treatment course had been relatively uncomplicated, aside from chemotherapy-induced pancytopenia requiring frequent red-cell and platelet transfusions. Four hours before the hypoxemic episode, she had received furosemide and albumin for lower-extremity edema, as well as a 10-pack of platelets because her platelet count was only 9000 per mm3 .
A chest radiograph reveals diffuse bilateral pulmonary alveolar opacities that were not evident yesterday. Other than a temperature of 38.1°C, the patient’s vital signs are stable on mechanical ventilation. Her respiratory examination reveals bilateral crackles. She has moderate, symmetric pedal edema. She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely to be responsible for this patient’s acute clinical deterioration?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced pneumonitis and eosinophilic pneumonia are drug-related pneumonias that mimic ARDS; however, they are less common than TRALI and have a distinct underlying pathophysiology. Although the initial presentation can vary, both conditions are often associated with a nonproductive cough and dyspnea, and the presentation is generally not as acute as that of TRALI.

B) INCORRECT:

Bacterial pneumonia usually manifests more gradually and with associated symptoms of fever and purulent secretions. It is less likely than TRALI in a patient who recently completed a course of antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspiration pneumonitis can also cause ARDS but is less likely in the setting of a recent blood-product transfusion without altered mental status or a witnessed aspiration.

D) CORRECT:

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), a common cause of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) in cancer patients, should be suspected when symptoms surface within 4 hours after blood-product transfusion. TRALI is most often associated with fresh frozen plasma and platelet transfusion, but it can also occur after red-cell transfusion. TRALI-related ARDS is caused by neutrophil-mediated, cytokine-induced pulmonary capillary leakage, prompting interstitial fluid to flood the alveolar space.

Key learning point: A patient who develops acute respiratory distress within 4 hours after a blood-product transfusion should be evaluated for transfusion-related acute lung injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced pneumonitis and eosinophilic pneumonia are drug-related pneumonias that mimic ARDS; however, they are less common than TRALI and have a distinct underlying pathophysiology. Although the initial presentation can vary, both conditions are often associated with a nonproductive cough and dyspnea, and the presentation is generally not as acute as that of TRALI.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman being treated with induction chemotherapy for acute myeloid leukemia develops chills and a 1.2°C increase in body temperature, without any shortness of breath or change in blood pressure, 2 hours after receiving one unit of group B, Rh-negative packed red cells. Her blood group is B, Rh-positive; she did not receive any premedication.
After she receives 650 mg of acetaminophen, her fever subsides. A clerical check confirms she received the correct unit of blood; retesting of a sample from the transfused blood showed that it had been typed correctly.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Check the serum lactate dehydrogenase level
Measure the panel reactive antibody level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Obtaining a serum lactate dehydrogenase level is not helpful because although it may be elevated in the setting of a hemolytic transfusion reaction, it is not specific.

B) INCORRECT:

Measuring the panel reactive antibody level is not helpful because it detects antibodies toward human leukocyte antigens, which are not targets of hemolytic transfusion reactions.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has experienced a febrile transfusion reaction, which is defined as fever >38°C or an increase of at least 1°C from baseline that occurs during or up to 4 hours after a blood transfusion and might be accompanied by chills. Most febrile transfusion reactions are nonhemolytic, but clinicians should always exclude hemolysis by checking that the correct unit was infused and performing a direct antiglobulin test. A positive direct antiglobulin test indicates that an immune mechanism is the cause of the hemolysis.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test for a patient who becomes febrile after receiving a correctly matched unit of packed red cells is a postreaction direct antiglobulin test to rule out a hemolytic transfusion reaction.

D) INCORRECT:

A chest radiograph would be helpful if there was concern for a transfusion-related fluid overload or acute lung injury, but this is not applicable because the patient does not have shortness of breath or changes in blood pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

Most febrile transfusion reactions are nonhemolytic, but clinicians should always exclude hemolysis by checking that the correct unit was infused and performing a direct antiglobulin test.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man with amyloidosis receives two units of packed red cells as treatment for severe symptomatic anemia. After 350 mL are infused, he develops shortness of breath and cough. His blood pressure increases from 120/65 mm Hg to 165/90 mm Hg, his temperature remains at 37.0°C, his heart rate increases from 65 to 104 beats per minute, and his oxygen saturation drops to 85% while he is breathing ambient air. Supplemental oxygen is provided, but the patient has an inadequate response and endotracheal intubation is required.
Physical examination reveals bulging neck veins.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following approaches could have prevented this transfusion reaction?

choices.text: Administering blood from an Rh-negative donor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen and leukoreduction prevent febrile nonhemolytic reaction, and irradiation only prevents graft-versus-host disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen and leukoreduction prevent febrile nonhemolytic reaction, and irradiation only prevents graft-versus-host disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen and leukoreduction prevent febrile nonhemolytic reaction, and irradiation only prevents graft-versus-host disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Rh-negative blood is usually indicated for Rh-negative patients, especially for women during childbirth.

E) CORRECT:

This patient had known amyloidosis and despite the absence of symptoms of heart failure, the heart stiffness from amyloid infiltration dramatically reduced his physiologic reserve. Small increases in intravascular volume can precipitate acute decompensation and heart failure. In most settings of transfusion, more units are transfused before one precipitates heart failure.

Older patients, children, and patients with renal or cardiac failure are at increased risk for transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). TACO is defined as new onset or exacerbation of at least three of the following conditions within 6 hours after completion of the transfusion:

• Acute respiratory distress (dyspnea, orthopnea, cough)
• Evidence of positive fluid balance
• Elevated brain natriuretic peptide level
• Radiographic evidence of pulmonary edema
• Evidence of left heart failure
• Elevated central venous pressure

TACO may be distinguished from transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) by the presence of hypertension and distended neck veins suggesting increased central venous pressure. TRALI is more commonly associated with hypotension and normal central venous pressure.

TACO can be treated with oxygen and diuretics, and it can be prevented by reducing the infusion rate to 2–4 milliliters per minute or 1 milliliter per kilogram of body weight per hour.

Key learning point: The correct diagnosis for a patient who develops acute respiratory distress and evidence of heart failure after receiving a red-cell transfusion is transfusion-associated circulatory overload.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman is scheduled for a liver biopsy. She has advanced cirrhosis secondary to hepatitis C virus infection and associated thrombocytopenia. Her platelet count is 25,000 per mm3 (reference range, 150,000–350,000).
A unit of apheresis random-donor platelets is ordered before the biopsy. Two minutes after the transfusion begins, the patient develops severe shortness of breath with stridor, hypoxemia, and hypotension but remains afebrile.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s transfusion reaction?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Citrate toxicity, which usually occurs in apheresis donors and rarely in recipients, manifests as nausea and vomiting.

B) INCORRECT:

Transfusion-associated circulatory overload is characterized by positive fluid balance and hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacterial contamination is usually associated with an increase in body temperature of at least 2°C from baseline and is not typically associated with other components of this patient’s presentation.

D) CORRECT:

Allergic transfusion reactions are common, with an estimated incidence of 1 to 3 per 100 transfusions. However, anaphylactic transfusion reactions are uncommon, with an estimated incidence of 1.7 to 4.3 per 100,000 red-cell and plasma transfusions and 62.6 per 100,000 platelet pools. Anaphylaxis, associated with hypotension and hypoxemia, occurs quickly after exposure to the allergen.

Among the many other causes of severe allergic reactions to transfusions are direct infusion of allergens (donor-ingested foods and medications); polymorphic forms of serum proteins (e.g., immunoglobulin A, haptoglobin, complement C3/4, transferrin, albumin, and others) to which the patient has been presensitized; passive transfer of immunoglobulin E antibodies to common environmental allergens; and anaphylatoxins or platelet biologic-response mediators generated during storage.

Key learning point: A patient with shortness of breath, hypoxemia, and hypotension immediately following the start of a blood or blood-product transfusion is most likely to be experiencing an anaphylactic reaction.

E) INCORRECT:

Transfusion-associated lung injury reaction typically manifests with sudden onset of hypoxemia and can also be associated with hypotension. However, onset within minutes of the transfusion being started would not be consistent with this condition, which usually manifests 1 to 6 hours after the transfusion is initiated. In addition, the presence of stridor is not consistent with transfusion-associated lung injury.

questions.text:
While awaiting upper endoscopy, a 31-year-old woman with hematemesis and acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding receives a transfusion containing one unit of packed red cells. Approximately 15 minutes into the transfusion, the patient develops chills, fever, chest pain, and hypotension.
One of the nurses realizes that the administered blood product had been intended for a trauma patient with a similar last name.
The transfusion is stopped, urgent therapy is given, and the blood bank is notified.
What error-prevention strategy should be emphasized in debriefing the medical team after this critical incident?

choices.text: Ask the patient to identify his or her blood group before administering a transfusion
Routinely confirm with the patient that he or she was expecting a transfusion before administering it
Encourage providers to speak up if they spot an error
Check at least two patient identifiers before administering a transfusion
Designate one health care provider to oversee the entire transfusion process from order to administration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Few patients know their blood group and recall it accurately, so self-reported blood group is considered unreliable.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients are sometimes unaware of or have misunderstood the provider’s plans for a transfusion. Asking an awake, competent patient to state his or her name before the transfusion is generally recommended but on its own, it might not have prevented the error in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Speaking up when observing an error is important, but on its own, it would not have prevented the error in this case.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms of fever, chest pain, and hypotension support the diagnosis of an acute hemolytic reaction caused by the transfusion of ABO-incompatible blood. Most hemolytic reactions are caused by human error. Therefore, in high-stakes situations, such as transfusion of blood products, the standard of care is to verify the patient's identity using at least two identifiers (such as name, medical record number, and date of birth listed on wristband) before transfusing blood.

Key learning point: Potentially fatal complications from transfusion of a mismatched blood product can be avoided by verifying the patient’s identity using at least two identifiers (e.g., name, medical record number, date of birth listed on wristband).

E) INCORRECT:

Limiting the blood-transfusion process to a single provider, from the initial order to the moment of transfusion, may minimize mistakes associated with handoffs. However, even if one provider ordered and gave the transfusion, the patient's identity must be verified before transfusing blood to ensure that the correct blood is given to the correct patient.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with a history of von Willebrand disease presents with jaundice and mild body aches. Two weeks ago, she had presented to the emergency department (ED) with tachycardia and headache in the setting of recent heavy menstrual bleeding. At that time, she had a history of one prior red-cell transfusion, she stated that she had not taken her oral contraceptive pills during the previous 3 weeks, and she had a hemoglobin concentration of 7 g/dL (reference range, 12–16) and a heart rate of 110 beats per minute. During that visit, she received a one-unit transfusion of ABO-matched packed red cells and was restarted on oral contraceptives.
On examination today, her temperature is 38.3°C, and she has bilateral scleral icterus, but the rest of her vital signs and physical examination are normal.
Repeat laboratory evaluation reveals normal leukocyte and platelet counts, a hemoglobin concentration of 10 g/dL (12–16), a total bilirubin level of 4.7 mg/dL (<1.5) with a conjugated component of 0.4 mg/dL (<0.2), and a lactate dehydrogenase level of 625 U/liter (100–190). Direct antibody testing is positive.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hereditary spherocytosis is characterized by hemolytic anemia caused by a red-cell membrane defect. This membrane defect causes a change in the shape of the red cell, making the cell spherical and more susceptible to hemolysis. The hemolysis in hereditary spherocytosis is not antibody-mediated; as such, direct antibody testing is negative in these patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV), a member of the herpes simplex virus family, infects people of all ages. Acute CMV infection in immunocompetent patients is frequently asymptomatic but may cause a mononucleosis-like infection associated with fever, fatigue, pharyngitis, adenopathy, and hepatitis. Laboratory studies may show abnormal leukocyte counts, elevated aminotransferase levels, and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (rather than the unconjugated form seen in this patient).

C) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 infection, which is common in children, can have a range of clinical manifestations. Most often, patients develop erythema infectiosum (i.e., fifth disease), characterized by fever and an erythematous malar ("slapped cheek") rash followed by a reticulated rash on the extremities. Parvovirus B19 infection can also cause arrest of red-cell maturation in the bone marrow, leading to a transient aplastic crisis. It does not cause hemolysis and is not associated with the receipt of blood products.

D) INCORRECT:

Gilbert syndrome is a genetic disorder of bilirubin metabolism characterized by a mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is caused by a mutation in the UGT1A1 gene. Patients with Gilbert syndrome exhibit intermittent jaundice, often during times of illness, fasting, or other physical stress. They do not have clinical or laboratory evidence of liver disease or hemolysis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient is experiencing a delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR), a rare complication of red-cell transfusion. DHTRs can occur 3 to 30 days after red-cell transfusion and are caused by an antibody response to a foreign red-cell antigen that the patient was previously exposed to — for example, during prior transfusions or during pregnancy. DHTRs are not the result of medical error (i.e., administration of unmatched blood), as the degree of antibody present at the time of transfusion cannot be detected.

DHTRs are characterized by extravascular hemolysis and may manifest with low-grade fevers, jaundice, and body aches or be clinically silent. Laboratory studies typically show markers of hemolysis, including an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, a low haptoglobin level, and positive direct-antibody results. Depending on the degree of hemolysis, patients may have lower-than-expected hemoglobin levels. In cases of very slow hemolysis, other markers of hemolysis may be normal.

Key learning point: Patients who have mild fever, jaundice, body aches, laboratory markers of hemolysis, and positive results on direct antibody testing 3 to 30 days after receiving a red-cell transfusion are likely to be experiencing a delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman develops chills and right flank pain while awaiting an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. She was admitted to the hospital with hematemesis and received one unit of packed red blood cells 30 minutes ago. The patient has no history of previous transfusions. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
8.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7500/mm3



Platelet count
180,000/mm3



Serum



 Total bilirubin
4.0 mg/dL


 Lactate dehydrogenase

700 U/L


A direct antiglobulin test (Coombs test) is positive. The transfusion is stopped, and the blood bank is notified of a suspected transfusion reaction. A debriefing and clinical peer review with the medical team and blood bank personnel is convened following the incident. Which of the following measures should be emphasized during this meeting to prevent the type of transfusion-related complication that occurred in this scenario?

choices.text: Use of a computerized system to track and screen blood donors
Checking at least two patient identifiers before administering a transfusion
Maintaining cold chain storage while the blood product is in transit from the blood bank
Storing packed red cell products in the blood bank only after they have been washed
Use of an infusion pump with a preset maximum flow rate during transfusion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Computerized systems for tracking and screening blood donors can prevent the transmission of infectious diseases and identify blood products that are associated with a high risk of certain complications (e.g., transfusion-related acute lung injury with blood products from multiparous donors). However, such a system is not effective in preventing AHTRs. The errors that lead to AHTRs typically occur during recipient identification, sample collection, labeling, or administration, rather than in the donor screening process.

B) CORRECT:

An ABO-incompatible transfusion, which is the most likely cause of this patient's immune AHTR, is a never event. The transfusion process includes several steps such as identifying the patient’s blood group, placing the order, identifying a matched blood product, labeling and dispensing the blood product, and administering the product to the correct patient. Errors can occur at any stage of this process but the most common causes of ABO-incompatible transfusions are blood product administration errors and wrong blood in tube (WBIT) errors. A strategy of conducting two determinations of the patient’s ABO group (e.g., by testing a second sample) can reduce the risk of misidentification during pretransfusion testing and mitigate the impact of WBIT errors. Not all patients know and recall their blood group accurately, so a self-reported blood group is not reliable. Blood product administration errors, such as transfusing an RBC unit to the wrong patient, account for about one-third of cases and can be prevented through final bedside verification of the patient’s identity against the transfusion order and blood product. Before every transfusion, this should be done using at least two identifiers (e.g., name, date of birth). Limiting the blood transfusion process to a single provider, from the initial order to the moment of transfusion, may minimize mistakes associated with handoffs.

C) INCORRECT:

Maintaining proper cold chain storage is crucial for ensuring the viability and safety of certain blood products (e.g., packed red blood cells). However, this measure primarily aims to prevent transfusion-related sepsis caused by the growth of pathogens in blood products. Non-immune AHTRs due to thermal damage to erythrocytes are rare and unlikely in this patient, who has a positive direct antiglobulin test, indicating an immune-mediated mechanism.

D) INCORRECT:

Routine washing of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) is not recommended as it reduces shelf life and is costly. It is only considered in specific situations, such as when there is a risk of anaphylactic reactions to transfusions (e.g., IgA-depleted blood products for patients with selective IgA deficiency). This case involves an immune AHTR, which is a type II hypersensitivity reaction, not anaphylaxis. While washing reduces donor anti-A and anti-B antibody levels in the blood product, immune AHTRs are primarily caused by recipient antibodies. Donor antibodies only become relevant as a cause of AHTR when large volumes of ABO-incompatible plasma are transfused, not with a single pRBC transfusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Slowing the rate of transfusion helps to prevent transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), which typically occurs during or within 12 hours of transfusion. However, TACO is associated with findings of hypervolemia (e.g., pulmonary edema, jugular venous distention), not hypovolemia. AHTR cannot be effectively prevented by limiting the transfusion rate.
questions.hint: Fever, chills, costovertebral angle tenderness, hypotension, and hemolysis occurring immediately after transfusion are consistent with an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR). The positive direct antiglobulin test indicates an immune-mediated mechanism, and the absence of a prior transfusion history makes non-ABO-related immune AHTR unlikely.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, is brought to the emergency department at 39 weeks' gestation in active labor. The patient has sickle cell disease. She has had multiple episodes of acute chest syndrome and has required several transfusions in the past. An uncomplicated cesarean section is performed with approx. 550 mL blood loss. Following the surgery, the patient continues to bleed, and she receives a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells. One hour later, the patient begins to have flank pain and appears to be in acute distress. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 99/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Foley catheter shows dark brown urine. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Serum antibodies against Class I HLA antigens
Low levels of serum IgA immunoglobulins
Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest x-ray

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum antibodies directed against donor HLA antigens have been associated with febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTRs), as the antibodies may bind to HLA antigens on residual donor leukocytes in blood products and possibly stimulate the release of inflammatory cytokines, which could cause fever and tachypnea. However, FNHTR does not result in hypotension. More importantly, the presence of hemoglobinuria and flank pain indicate that the patient has intravascular hemolysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Low levels of serum IgA immunoglobulins would be consistent with selective IgA deficiency. Patients with selective IgA deficiency have antibodies against IgA, which then mediate an allergic response and anaphylaxis during transfusion of blood products that incidentally contain donor IgA. While this patient's acute distress, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension might be consistent with an anaphylactic response, the absence of corresponding angioedema, pulmonary (dyspnea, wheezing) and skin findings (urticaria, pruritus, flush) are not consistent with this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Positive blood cultures in the postpartum period might suggest a diagnosis of puerperal sepsis, which can manifest with fever, hypotension, tachypnea, and tachycardia. While this patient currently has a number of findings that might raise concerns of sepsis, there is no evidence of a surgical site infection (e.g., purulent discharge from the wound), endometritis/parametritis (e.g., foul-smelling lochia, subinvolution of the uterus, cervical motion tenderness), or peritonitis (e.g., abdominal guarding, rigidity) to suggest a focus for puerperal sepsis in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

A positive direct Coombs test indicates that RBCs in the patient's blood have bound antibodies. This laboratory result would be consistent with a diagnosis of AHTR, in which donor RBC lysis is mediated by preformed antibodies in the patient's serum. AHTRs are most commonly due to ABO incompatibility, and less commonly due to a mismatch and incompatibility of minor RBC antigens (e.g., anti-Jka, anti-Rh, etc.). Patients with a history of previous transfusions, especially those with sickle cell disease, are more likely to be subject to alloimmunization against foreign blood product antigens and subsequently have transfusion-related complications, including but not limited to AHTRs.

See “Overview of immunological transfusion reactions” table.
Image Description:

A test used to detect hemolytic antibodies bound to RBCs (direct Coombs test) or freely circulating in the serum (indirect Coombs test).

1. The direct Coombs test is used to detect hemolytic antibodies or complement bound to the surface of a patient's erythrocytes. It is used to differentiate between autoimmune and nonimmune hemolytic anemias and to diagnose hemolytic diseases of the fetus and newborn.

2. The indirect Coombs test is used to detect hemolytic anti-RBC IgG antibodies (against foreign RBC antigens) present in a patient's serum. It is used to screen for maternal anti-D IgG antibodies (detection of hemolytic disease of the newborn) and to crossmatch blood before transfusions.

E) INCORRECT:

Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates that develop within 6 hours of transfusion of a blood product may indicate either transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) or transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Both TRALI and TACO can manifest with acute distress, tachypnea, and tachycardia, and patients with TRALI may also develop fever and hypotension. However, patients with TRALI or TACO would present with hypoxemia as a result of respiratory insufficiency and bilateral crackles due to pulmonary edema. Moreover, patients with TACO are usually afebrile and hypertensive rather than hypotensive, given their state of circulatory overload. Together with the normal SpO2, the absence of these findings makes these diagnoses unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient developed a fever, hypotension, tachypnea, tachycardia, flank pain, and hemoglobinuria within 1–2 hours of receiving a blood transfusion, which is consistent with an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR).

questions.text: A 24-year-old man develops respiratory distress in the postoperative ward 2 hours after surgical repair of an open midshaft fracture of the right femur. During the procedure, he received 6 units of packed red blood cells, 1 unit of platelets, and 4 units of fresh frozen plasma. On admission to the postoperative ward, his vitals were within normal limits. Now, his temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 78%. Bibasilar crackles are heard on auscultation. Chest x-ray shows diffuse, bilateral infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's deterioration?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a transfusion reaction caused by the activation of the recipient's granulocytes by soluble factors (e.g., antibodies) in the donor's blood. Activated granulocytes release proinflammatory mediators that increase the vascular permeability, resulting in plasma transudation into the pulmonary interstitium and consequent noncardiogenic pulmonary edema. TRALI typically occurs during or within 6 hours of transfusion. Patients usually present with hypoxemic respiratory insufficiency, features of pulmonary edema (e.g., crackles, bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray), and signs of hypovolemia (hypotension, tachycardia). Signs of hypovolemia distinguish TRALI from transfusion-associated circulatory overload, which, in contrast to TRALI, characteristically manifests with findings of volume overload (e.g., elevated blood pressure, S3 gallop, jugular venous distension). Immediate cessation of any ongoing transfusion followed by supportive treatment with respiratory and circulatory support is recommended.
Image Description:

TRALI: Transfusion-related acute lung injury; Ag: antigen

B) INCORRECT:

Postoperative bronchospasm is a common complication following general anesthesia and typically manifests with sudden-onset respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and tachycardia. However, lung auscultation typically shows wheezing, which is not seen here. Moreover, bibasilar crackles and diffuse, bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray are not characteristic of bronchospasm.

C) INCORRECT:

Sepsis can manifest with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, tachycardia, and fever. Although this patient fulfills the diagnostic criteria for systemic inflammatory response syndrome (i.e., heart rate > 90/min and respiratory rate > 20/min), a diagnosis of sepsis requires a suspected or confirmed underlying infection. This patient had no signs of infection on admission, and wound infections and/or hospital-acquired pneumonia typically do not develop within 4 hours.

D) INCORRECT:

Fat embolism can manifest with hypoxemic respiratory distress, signs of hypovolemia, and diffuse, bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray (as a result of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema). However, neurological symptoms (e.g., altered mental status) would also be expected, and the symptoms of fat embolism typically develop 12–72 hours after the inciting event.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient after physical trauma

Parenchymal opacities (green overlay) are seen in both lungs, predominantly in the lower zones. No pleural effusions are visible (indicated by red overlay). The cardiac silhouette is not enlarged. A right central line is present (yellow outline). The radiopaque line on a nasogastric tube (blue overlay) can be traced into the mid-thorax, beyond which it is not well seen.

Nonspecific homogeneous or heterogeneous opacities may become visible on chest radiographs in various locations about 24–48 hours after an insult that results in pulmonary fat embolism. A normal cardiac silhouette size and absence of Kerley lines, pleural effusions, and pulmonary venous hypertension can help exclude a diagnosis of cardiogenic edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Volume overload can manifest with respiratory distress and pulmonary edema after surgery that involves aggressive hemodynamic support. However, signs of hypervolemia (e.g., hypertension, S3 gallop, jugular venous distension) rather than hypovolemia are expected in a patient with volume overload.
questions.hint: This patient presents with hypoxemic respiratory insufficiency, features of pulmonary edema (e.g., crackles, bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray), and signs of hypovolemia (hypotension, tachycardia) following major surgery that required aggressive hemodynamic support, including blood products.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with severe menorrhagia for 3 days. She also reports dizziness. She appears pale. Vital signs are within normal limits. Her hemoglobin concentration is 5.9 g/dL. Crystalloid fluids are administered and she is transfused with 4 units of crossmatched packed red blood cells. Two hours later, she has shortness of breath and dull chest pressure. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 170/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. Diffuse crackles are heard over the lower lung fields on auscultation. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral hazy opacities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening type 1 hypersensitivity reaction that can occur during blood product transfusion and manifests with bronchospasm, urticaria, and hypotension (shock). This patient presents with crackles, not wheezes, and lacks other features of anaphylaxis. Additionally, the delayed time course in this patient's presentation makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a rare but dangerous complication of transfusion of blood products that usually occurs within the first 6 hours after transfusion and can manifest with acute dyspnea and diffuse bilateral opacities on chest x-ray. However, hypotension and fever would also be expected, whereas this patient is hypertensive and afebrile.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism (PE) can manifest with tachycardia, dyspnea, and hypoxia, as seen in this patient. However, a chest x-ray is usually normal in PE or shows nonspecific findings. In addition, PEs are usually associated with hypotension (rather than hypertension) and the chest pain in PE is classically pleuritic, rather than a dull chest pressure. PE would also not explain this patient's S3 gallop.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction manifests with fever, chills, nausea, hypotension, and flank pain and typically occurs during transfusion of incompatible blood products. Although symptoms can include shortness of breath, it is not associated with pulmonary edema or an S3 gallop, and the time course of this patient's presentation is not consistent with this diagnosis. Furthermore, hemolytic transfusion reaction is unlikely to occur with blood products that have been crossmatched correctly.

E) CORRECT:

Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) refers to volume overload that has developed secondary to the transfusion of blood products. It generally occurs within 12 hours of transfusion and is characterized by hypertension, wide pulse pressure, and evidence of volume overload (pulmonary edema, S3 gallop, jugular venous distention). Risk increases with the number of units transfused and can be minimized by increasing time intervals between transfusions and limiting the rate of intravenous administration. Treatment usually involves the use of supplemental oxygen and mobilization of fluid with diuresis.

See “Differentiating between transfusion-related acute lung injury and transfusion-associated circulatory overload” table.
questions.hint: This patient's hypoxia, bibasilar crackles, and hazy opacities on chest x-ray suggest pulmonary edema.

questions.text:
Two hours after undergoing a platelet transfusion, a 55-year-old man develops fever, chills, and headache. He was admitted to the hospital 4 hours ago for an uncontrolled nosebleed. The platelet count at the time of admission was 33,000/mm3. Medical history is remarkable for multiple myeloma complicated by bone marrow failure. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 143/96 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor, scattered petechiae on his upper and lower extremities, and gauze packing in the nasal cavity. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11 g/dL


Platelet count
57,000/mm3



Serum



Total bilirubin
0.4 mg/dL


Lactate dehydrogenase
90 U/L


A direct antiglobulin test (Coombs test) is negative. Blood cultures grow no organisms. Which of the following measures would most likely have prevented this patient's transfusion-related complication?

choices.text: Using platelet concentrate only from male donors and screening for antineutrophil antibodies
Leukoreduction of the platelet concentrate before storage
System-based training of health care personnel for proper patient identification

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Premedication with antihistamines is used in patients with a history of moderate to severe allergic transfusion reactions to reduce the incidence and severity of subsequent reactions. Allergic reactions are common in patients receiving platelet transfusions and usually develop within 4 hours of transfusion. However, the absence of wheezing, hypotension, and shortness of breath makes a severe allergic transfusion reaction unlikely. Premedication with antihistamines is not indicated for FNHTR.

B) INCORRECT:

Using platelet concentrate only from male donors and screening for antineutrophil antibodies decreases the risk of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), which most commonly occurs after platelet transfusion and manifests with fever within 6 hours of transfusion. TRALI cases are more commonly associated with female and multiparous donors than male donors. However, TRALI is associated with dyspnea, hypotonia, hypotension, and findings of pulmonary edema (e.g., crackles on auscultation), none of which are seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Slowing the rate of transfusion helps to prevent transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), which typically occurs during or within 12 hours of transfusion. However, TACO is associated with findings of hypervolemia (e.g., dyspnea, S3 gallop, jugular venous distention, hypertension) and pulmonary edema (e.g., crackles on auscultation).

D) CORRECT:

Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTRs) result from the leakage of preformed cytokines produced by donor leukocytes and accumulated during the storage of blood products; lysis of donor leukocytes by preformed recipient antibodies has also been implicated. Prestorage leukoreduction, e.g., by ultrafiltration, decreases the number of donor leukocytes available within blood products and, therefore, helps to prevent FNHTRs. FNHTRs are a diagnosis of exclusion; the first step in the management of suspected FNHTR is the cessation of transfusion to rule out more serious transfusion reactions (e.g., acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, transfusion-associated sepsis, transfusion-related acute lung injury). An antipyretic such as acetaminophen can be given to treat the fever and, if the patient remains stable without new symptoms, the transfusion can be recommenced at a slow rate.

E) INCORRECT:

System-based training of health care personnel for proper patient identification can reduce the incidence of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) due to ABO mismatch (a never event), which manifests with fever and chills within the first 24 hours after transfusion. However, patients also typically present with flank pain, features of hemolysis (e.g., elevated LDH, indirect hyperbilirubinemia), and a positive direct antiglobulin test, none of which are seen here. Unlike RBC concentrates, platelet concentrates are usually transfused without crossmatching because ABO antigens are poorly expressed on platelets; therefore, proper patient identification would not help to prevent platelet-associated transfusion reactions.
questions.hint: The combination of fever, chills, and headache occurring 1–6 hours posttransfusion in a hemodynamically stable patient with no evidence of hemolysis (i.e., normal LDH and total bilirubin), a negative direct antiglobulin test, and negative blood culture is consistent with febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR).

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with upper gastrointestinal bleeding related to erosive gastritis requires a transfusion of packed red cells. During the transfusion, he develops a mild itchy rash on his chest and arms but remains afebrile and hemodynamically stable. Which one of the following types of transfusion reaction is most likely occurring in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions typically develop 3 days to 2 weeks after a transfusion and are caused by the prior production of alloantibodies against erythrocyte antigens, such as in the setting of pregnancy or transfusion. Patients may be asymptomatic, but laboratory tests will show markers of hemolysis.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is experiencing mild allergic symptoms (hives) but does not demonstrate signs or symptoms of anaphylaxis, such as gastrointestinal distress, hypotension, or airway compromise. Therefore, he is likely experiencing a simple allergic transfusion reaction rather than an anaphylactic transfusion reaction. These reactions are typically mediated by immunoglobulin E antibodies against donor plasma antigens and may vary in severity.

Key learning point: Allergic transfusion reactions are mediated by immunoglobulin E, characterized by classic allergic symptoms, and may be mild or severe.

C) INCORRECT:

Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions are due to cytokine accumulation in stored blood products and are more likely to occur with platelet transfusions than red-cell transfusions. This type of reaction is characterized by an increase in body temperature of more than 1°C during transfusion or within 6 hours post-transfusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Transfusion-associated circulatory overload is most common in patients at risk for volume overload. It is characterized by cardiogenic pulmonary edema and respiratory distress that occur during transfusion or up to a few hours post-transfusion.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient is experiencing mild allergic symptoms (hives) but does not demonstrate signs or symptoms of anaphylaxis, such as gastrointestinal distress, hypotension, or airway compromise. Therefore, he is likely experiencing a simple allergic transfusion reaction rather than an anaphylactic transfusion reaction.
questions.hint: This type of transfusion reaction typically develops during or up to 4 hours after transfusion.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with a history of von Willebrand disease presents with jaundice and mild body aches. Two weeks ago, she had presented to the emergency department with tachycardia and headache in the setting of recent heavy menstrual bleeding. At that time, she had a history of one prior red-cell transfusion, she stated that she had not taken her oral contraceptive pills during the previous 3 weeks, and she had a hemoglobin concentration of 7 g/dL and a heart rate of 110/min. During that visit, she received a one-unit transfusion of ABO-matched packed red cells and was restarted on oral contraceptives. On examination today, her temperature is 38.3°C, and she has bilateral scleral icterus, but the rest of her vital signs and physical examination are normal. Repeat laboratory evaluation reveals normal leukocyte and platelet counts, a hemoglobin concentration of 10 g/dL, a total bilirubin level of 4.7 mg/dL with a conjugated component of 0.4 mg/dL, and a lactate dehydrogenase level of 625 U/L. Direct antibody testing is positive. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hereditary spherocytosis is characterized by hemolytic anemia caused by a red-cell membrane defect. This membrane defect causes a change in the shape of the red cell, making the cell spherical and more susceptible to hemolysis. The hemolysis in hereditary spherocytosis is not antibody-mediated; as such, direct antibody testing is negative in these patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV), a member of the herpes simplex virus family, infects people of all ages. Acute CMV infection in immunocompetent patients is frequently asymptomatic but may cause a mononucleosis-like infection associated with fever, fatigue, pharyngitis, adenopathy, and hepatitis. Laboratory studies may show abnormal leukocyte counts, elevated aminotransferase levels, and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (rather than the unconjugated form seen in this patient).

C) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 infection, which is common in children, can have a range of clinical manifestations. Most often, patients develop erythema infectiosum (i.e., fifth disease), characterized by fever and an erythematous malar ("slapped cheek") rash followed by a reticulated rash on the extremities. Parvovirus B19 infection can also cause arrest of red-cell maturation in the bone marrow, leading to a transient aplastic crisis. It does not cause hemolysis and is not associated with the receipt of blood products.

D) INCORRECT:

Gilbert syndrome is a genetic disorder of bilirubin metabolism characterized by a mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is caused by a mutation in the UGT1A1 gene. Patients with Gilbert syndrome exhibit intermittent jaundice, often during times of illness, fasting, or other physical stress. They do not have clinical or laboratory evidence of liver disease or hemolysis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient is experiencing a delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR), a rare complication of red-cell transfusion. DHTRs can occur 3 to 30 days after red-cell transfusion and are caused by an antibody response to a foreign red-cell antigen that the patient was previously exposed to — for example, during prior transfusions or during pregnancy. DHTRs are not the result of medical error (i.e., administration of unmatched blood), as the degree of antibody present at the time of transfusion cannot be detected.

DHTRs are characterized by extravascular hemolysis and may manifest with low-grade fevers, jaundice, and body aches or be clinically silent. Laboratory studies typically show markers of hemolysis, including an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, a low haptoglobin level, and positive direct-antibody results. Depending on the degree of hemolysis, patients may have lower-than-expected hemoglobin levels. In cases of very slow hemolysis, other markers of hemolysis may be normal.

Key learning point: Patients who have mild fever, jaundice, body aches, laboratory markers of hemolysis, and positive results on direct antibody testing 3 to 30 days after receiving a red-cell transfusion are likely to be experiencing a delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction.
questions.hint: Most cases are self-limited and thus no acute therapy is usually required.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman is scheduled for a liver biopsy. She has advanced cirrhosis secondary to hepatitis C virus infection and associated thrombocytopenia.
